segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Once again, thank you for coming, welcome to Sifcon, I guess.
It's really good to be here, I'd like to just in the beginning extend my deep gratitude
to the organiser for having me once again at this great conference, it's really one
of my favourite events in Poland, so yeah, it's good to be back here in Gdynia.
So what we're going to talk about today is Winti and why this title, the group that wasn't,
was it a group, what happened, we will learn just in a bit.
So a bit of the time schedule for today, first a short introduction of why I'm even here
and why am I talking to you about this Winti group, second we will have a short introduction
on how to define the groups at all and what do we mean by group, what do we mean by threat
actor and so on, but the main body, the main part of the presentation will be analysis
of how the Winti discoveries, published research, disclosed campaigns and so much more unfolded
in terms of what was published and second an answer to those who might ask, so what,
what are the consequences of taking a certain approach and what can we learn from this group.
As we are here at ZipCon and this is red and blue conference, as you can see by my attire
I'm more aligned with the blue side, but on the side of the red I hope that it will also
support adversary emulation team with perhaps working on more high fidelity simulation if
the client or your customer will request that you need to emulate Winti.
So first of all who am I, I'm working daily as a principal intelligence analyst at Cointelligence,
so I mainly do threat research work and work directly with customers on providing tailored
intelligence briefings, intelligence solutions and supporting their security organisation.
Also from time to time students of SANS 4578 might meet me where I'm supporting SANS instructors
as a teaching assistant and I run my own personal blog where you can read some of my free thoughts
about the intelligence security, national security at counterintelligence.pl, feel free
to reach me either at the conference or at those addresses and just a standard disclaimer
that whatever I'll be saying today is purely my own conclusion, thoughts and so on and
do not represent the position of my company.
So just one more short disclaimer, because we will be talking of how the group unfolded
and what was the understanding of it, I will be naming and mentioning research of many
many great threat intelligence teams and by all means I do not mean that if I come to
a different conclusion they are wrong or their analysis was bad or something like that,
rather that because of different intelligence requirements we might approach the same situation
in different manners, so just a quick disclaimer that this is all the research I will present
is all very high quality, just we might have a different perspective.
So sliding right at the defining and tracking the various adversarial groups, basically
we might approach this issue in a twofold manner.
We might approach it by what's commonly called a threat actor, which is represented by this
nice FBI wanted poster on the right hand side and this is trying to establish exactly
who are those actors, so who are the people on the keyboard, operators and so on, like
having this very particular visibility into a specific unit that is conducting activity,
being it a criminal group or being it an intelligence unit or military unit.
In terms of WNT we will be talking about this APT41 cluster as defined by pretty much
United States government by now and is composed of the intelligence officers, but the other
solution that you might come across and approach is tracking it by just activity.
So the left hand illustration presents diamond model of intrusion analysis, which means that
you aim to break down the activity into specific observables such as the infrastructure use
capabilities, so the malware techniques, tactics and procedures for initial access, the victimology
and based on that, regardless of who is sitting at the keyboard, you will be tracking like
what is the representation of the group.
Okay so let's dive right in and so the question is who is this WNT hacker, what is going on
there?
And the answer is WNT is not a group, WNT is actually a malware, WNT is a remote access
trojan that's got the versions for Windows and Linux and has wide capabilities of allowing
operator to interact with systems and files, commands and so on.
So this is it, thank you for coming to my talk.
But on a more serious note, the WNT as a group has been first defined by Kaspersky, but the
kind of caveat is that it was not actually discovered by Kaspersky.
So what happened in 2013 is we had this very nice research piece from Kaspersky that described
a group that is using this WNT malware and stolen certificates to target video game companies.
Although there was here a short, let's say a disclaimer or there was a bit of a misnomer,
not misnomer, but the targeting was much wider because it also involved activist groups,
but in general because of this wide use of the WNT tool, so this remote access tool,
and because of the use of stolen certificates and because of the victimology that was kind
of defined, Kaspersky took this name that was originally discovered by Symantec, so
WNT malware group and decided that from now on they will be tracking this as the group
and if you can see here, perhaps not from the back of the hall, so at the very bottom
of the screenshot from Kaspersky is that we uncovered activity of the Chinese origins
and we tracked this activity as a WNT group.
So to further give you a background, the group was discovered even earlier, around 2010,
by 2013 community research, let's say, as a whole started tracking it, but by then the
activity was mainly focused on very much financially motivated actions, so they were breaching
these video game companies and they were stealing the source code or they were even doing cheats
in-game to gain the in-game currency for exchange, so it was essentially this quite advanced
malware was used to funnel the money out of gaming companies and we had stolen certificates,
so things were quite interesting to follow.
And then around the same time in 2013, FireEye, now Google Cloud's Mandiant, has published
a research and they seemed to get a sense of what is going on because they published
this very nice piece about the digital quartermaster, so they described how the various toolings
and infrastructure is shared among the various groups, which pointed them to the conclusion
that it is essentially like a development team, or the infrastructure creation team,
that supplies the tooling to various activity groups as they are tracked in a different
manner.
So we had essentially this idea that what the researchers were tracking was not so much
of a group of the hands-on keyboard operators, but the development team that was supplying
those tools.
And this will have quite a bit of ramification as we go further, but here you can see on
this bottom screenshot from the report, the quote was about the, it referenced directly
the Kaspersky report and the stolen certificates were in fact the same ones that were used
by the Winty cluster.
And the Winty itself by Mandiant I think is tracked as High Noon, and this was a part
of this, let's say, quartermaster report.
Then in 2014 we had a very extensive report on the activity that was tracked by essentially
a coalition of partners, there was Microsoft, Cisco, FireEye, EyeSight, Noveta, multiple
groups involved, and they published this research piece, Operation SMN, which as some
might know is an acronym for Some Marketing Name, because apparently they thought this
was an appropriate naming convention.
So this was a wide-ranging Chinese intelligence operation that targeted Fortune 500 companies,
aerospace industry, defense industry, all over the world.
And because of this visibility that was available to this multitude of companies, they could
track this whole cluster of what was going on, and in the additional research piece that
was published soon later on was the analysis of the further version of Winty malware.
So this was this link by the malware grouping.
And Noveta in this report, like we had now with FireEye and Kaspersky, also put the moderate
to high confidence of the Chinese intelligence operation.
So we had those links, we had those malware and infrastructure, but now some of you might
ask like what happened with the targeting and victims from the trying to get in-game
currency to targeting defense contractors.
So in fact in 2015 from Kaspersky there was another report on the Winty malware group,
which directly linked those efforts to the Axiom reporting, and Kaspersky claimed that
the samples they have seen are similar or analogous to what was reported in Operation
SMN, and because of that they tracked it further as this Winty activity.
But the victimology and targeting has now changed, and the targeting also in this Kaspersky
visibility moved more towards the pharmaceutical companies.
So perhaps a targeting more in line with what we saw from the Noveta report.
And very, very, let's say in the short time frame, Symantec published a research on the
groups they tracked as a black fly, in which they talked about the use of the stolen certificates
mainly, and how these certificates that were obtained from those also video game companies
were used for malware delivery purpose.
And the research indirectly referenced Kaspersky research, so as you might see on the screenshot
below, it says that third party vendor published, and because of the similarity in the malware
and the technique of stealing code signing certificates, we had this grouping from Symantec,
and now you might get a bit lost in this, so we will start with our first diagram.
So essentially what happened and how we arrived at this point is that initially the Winty
was discovered by Symantec as a malware group, then we had a grouping into the activity group
by Kaspersky, so Kaspersky, when they detected this malware, they decided to track it not
just as a detection of a sample of a group like Metroprater Cobblestring, but as a group,
and then it resulted in this Winty group, and when we go back, do a round, back to what
Symantec was saying, is that Symantec, when it was Winty joined with the stolen certificates,
they tracked it as black fly, and when it was some other custom tooling that was used
in the attacks, it was tracked as sack fly group.
And going further we can see that since around 2016, more and more vendors started, let's
say jumping on this research tray of the Winty group, and we had this blog from Silence,
now Blackberry Silence, about their research into so-called PASS-TV group that was targeting
once again gaming companies, and the link here, unfortunately, the links between the
groupings started being a bit more, let's say, disjoint, because what Silence team has
referenced is that because of the similarity in victimology of the stolen certificates
victims, so which companies were affected by this certificate theft, that was used then
to, that was used then to sign this malware, and because those victims were earlier breached
as referenced by other vendors as victims of Winty, we had this linking into their PASS-TV
group, as you can see, this conclusion that Winty and PASS-TV are closely related.
However, if we take like a step back from this, we actually see here that the, as I
noticed this link started getting a bit murky, because essentially we started from this tracking
by Winty, okay, so this is a malware specific to a given group, but at this point in some
vendor reporting, we are almost dropping this part of the conversation, let's say,
and when we look at this PASS-TV and how it was defined, it was because only of the some
certificates that were stolen from those companies, but the malware used mainly was of completely,
well, not completely, but was of a different kind, including some open source software.
So what happened in 2017 is that Microsoft took a tackle on this group, and they did
quite a thing, because they said that because of how these objectives and how the methods
differ between certain representations of Winty, they will take approach that they will
start tracking it as two groups.
So we had this, this was still when the Microsoft was using this element's name for the activity
group naming, so we had the Barium and Lead, and Barium represent more this part focus
on the, let's say, commercial activity, financially motivated activity, attacking of gaming companies,
trying to get these scams and going with in-game currency, and we had the Lead group,
which was more focused, let's say, on those high-value advanced target, industrial espionage
and trying to breach into defense contractors and so on.
So basically it looked like that, that the Microsoft took this grouping of Winty by the
malware and broke it down based on the victimology and on the techniques used, because they noticed
that for different targets, different initial access or delivery techniques were used, which
is quite interesting.
The Lead part, which was, let's say, more concerned with serious target, which was quite
a bit more direct with their approach, and they tended to just straight up directly send
the Winty executable to their victims by phishing mails.
On the other hand, the Barium group, which was more concerned with money and getting
the financial results of their operation, was actually quite proficient in building
rapport with their victims, doing social engineering work, building up on the relationship, sending
LNK files that were used then to deliver Winty as a second stage and so on and so on.
So as you hear on the left-hand side of the slide, we have this diamond model, this diamond
model node, because when, at the beginning of the presentation, I've talked about the
different scenarios or different approaches to grouping, the Microsoft explicitly, even
as they mentioned in this group, decided to go the activity group route and do not focus
so much on who is behind the keyboard or how the group is internally constructed, just
on the representation.
Then the Trend Micro also tried to take a job at tracking and defining how the Winty
works, but Trend Micro kind of stepped back into this idea of having the activity group
by the malware, so basically they said they talked about the Winty group but they tracked
the presentation of the malware and they found a very nice, they did a very nice research
about the use of GitHub for command and control communication, so the GitHub repositories
were used to host the commands that were fetched by the malware pieces and as such they represented
that it received the commands from the, essentially, attackers from C2.
Trend Micro went even further because they went on to track the infrastructure of the
attackers, they found this individual that was known as Hack520 on various social media
platforms and because of that they discovered the registration scheme and the ranges of
the VPS addressing that was used as part of this infrastructure.
So we had now this from Trend Micro, this bit of wider picture of having both the infrastructure
and malware, so perhaps even as they started from this very much, let's say, maybe less
defined malware based tracking, they expanded it into this technical axis of the Diamond
model into infrastructure and capabilities and they discovered that, pardon, they discovered
the guy behind this infrastructure is apparently a fan of pigs, he had a pet pig which is indeed
very cute and he was happy to post it on various social media which actually also helped with
tracking them because apparently pigs are not so common as pets.
Yeah, take your pictures.
So this is how it went for the Trend Micro.
Then what happened in terms of how the understanding of the group was developing was that in 2017
we had this report from 401 Threat Research Group and what happened there is that they
did actually a few pieces on the Winty but like the cornerstone, the punchline was that
they report on burning umbrellas, so they tracked the representation or the presentation
of the Winty in certain victimologies, they tracked down the infrastructure and they came
to the conclusion that it should be tracked as a single umbrella, which means that various
intelligence, Chinese intelligence operations are using similar backbone composed of the
TTPs like using our favourite Winty malware and using infrastructure that could be tracked
by certain characteristics and this backbone is used as an umbrella for various groups
like that are called Axiom, APT17, Lead Barium, Wicked Panda and so on by different actors
but initially it came from the same route, so either the same activity in terms of tasking
or this is one organisation that creates all those infrastructure and so on.
What is interesting for this report, they put a high confidence in attribution to this
Chinese intelligence apparatus, now from what was published and from my understanding this
is based purely on the analysis of the observables, there was no insight, they had no internal
knowledge about the intercepts of something that could point them further towards this
assessment, but apparently they felt that they have enough to link it back to the Chinese
intelligence, and it seems they were not entirely wrong in that, because by 2018 the United
States Department of Justice started getting involved also in tracking of Winty or maybe
not tracking but rather prosecuting, and there was a first indictment against officers
of the Jiangsu Province Ministry of State Security Department, and in this indictment
we can see that around 2012 members of the conspiracy installed this Winty malware on
the computers of the industrial company.
So interesting thing to note here is that while Kaspersky was tracking it when it was
discovered and reached public as a commercial financially motivated operation, we can see
that in fact even by 2012 this was already an industrial espionage outlet.
Similarly in 2019 we have seen this scent of this Linux version when the Chronicle posted
on their blog that there is not only Windows which is most popular, but also a Linux version
of the Winty RAT, and it dated back to 2015 and to the breaches against some Vietnamese
gaming companies, so we can see how those both streams, let's say lead and barium in
Microsoft terminology, were going in parallel.
And in 2019 also Asset published a very extensive piece on the arsenal and the activity of the
Winty group.
What I like in this report, they make quite clear that from their perspective Winty is
a group that performed these attacks using techniques and tooling described by them and
tracked, regardless of what is the underlying structure of the group.
So once again, similarly to maybe similarly to Microsoft or to other vendors that did
not care so much about the attribution, they just tried to get there by grouping up use
of certain techniques and use and how it was deployed.
And also the things that start getting up is that if you remember the supply chains
attacks that used for example CCCleaner or Asus Firmware Update, those attacks were also
linked to this activity through deployed artifacts and through the techniques used and how the
malware was constructed.
So we had now by this very quite a bit sprawling activity that involves both supply chain attacks
but delivery by social engineering infrastructure that was based in China and other regions,
a lot of victims and so on.
And in 2019 also Mandiant came up with this quite interesting scenario is that this Winty
which they tracked as APT41 is essentially the one operation but split between the official
part so intelligence officers doing their work and the moonlighting part, so intelligence
officers making money on the side by using the capabilities they have access to.
So yes, so as you see on the upper screenshot from the report, they mentioned the Barium
Group and Winty as what constitutes of this APT41 and below we can see one of the certificates
that was linked to this operation.
So actually Mandiant took an opposite approach to what Microsoft was doing with lead and
barium and we can mark it as this icon of the indictment.
They grouped together two branches of the operation, the financially motivated part
and the industrial espionage one, because they had correlation between used malware,
the specific mailing addresses that were used to deliver those and so on and generally having
the shared infrastructure that was used to deliver it.
So basically if you would turn these schemes upside down, you would see the division into
lead and barium actors.
And further in 2020, APT41 moniker was actually used by the United States Department of Justice
in another indictment, but this one was way more specific.
So earlier we just had this mention of industrial espionage operation using Winty malware, but
now we had explicit indictment, explicit finger pointing into this APT41 operation and pointing
out to specific operators that were conducting those operations as a part of the so-called
name and shame campaign, so the attempts of the United States government to impose cost
on the operations by publishing their official names, their personal details.
And as you can hear at the bottom of this part of the indictment, in fact we had this
confirmed by this official document, United States government grouping the activity by
the Plague X Winty but also Shadowpad, so one of the malware that was used in the supply
chain attack as far as I remember for Asus one.
So we had this more clarity, and in 2020 also my company, Quo Intelligence, we published
a research piece on the sample that we discovered that was used to attack the German chemical
company.
We had this, we had not only the code similarities but also this link by stolen certificates,
and we have also discovered how the DNS tunnelling was used to exfil data and as a C2 channel
essentially.
And here from how we, I mean we also used the Winty group moniker, but we had this very
direct link, we had this very direct link because we found sample that had significant
code similarities and significant overlap in the use of stolen certificates.
So we came to this very, very let's say one-to-one direct mapping into the capabilities that
were used earlier, but we saw those now deployed against different target, this chemical company,
but also South Korean gaming, but in general when we track back, and you can read it on
our blog, when we track back this activity, it went more into this lead branch, let's
say, in targeting various German industrial and technology companies.
And interestingly coming to our more recent times, in 2020 FireEyeMandiant tracked, published
report and now on tracked as APT41 against global intrusion against, as I believe, mainly
network devices, vulnerabilities in Citrix, NetScaler, Cisco routers and so on, but what
was interesting about this report is this is after the indictments by DOJ, so we had
this, let's say, official name of APT41 floating around, but here the tools used were not any
more winty, but we had our favourite CobaltStrike and Meterpreter used in those intrusions.
So let's say that by the Mandiant visibility, apparently they have capabilities to go a
bit deeper and kind of move away from having to have the winty malware included to track
further those capabilities.
And also then in 2022 we had Cyber Reason.
Cyber Reason did a very in-depth research on the new campaigns that they discovered
by tracking the intrusions where the winty malware was used.
They described in this two-part research how the malware was evolved to include more evasive
capabilities and so on, and again they had this high attribution to winty group, but
it was moderate high actually, but this is not very surprising given how it was tracked
by those various malware representations, and it showed, even when we go back to the
Noveta report, when they described the various versions of winty that were going further
from version 1.2.3, we can see that after 10 years around, the malware is in fact still
in development, which kind of speaks volumes to its role in those operations.
Also in 2022 we had the report from the group IB, another great vendor, and they did this
using the Mandiant moniker of APT41, and they described a very, very wide-ranging campaign
all over the world, Europe, America, Asia-Pacific, about the APT41 alleged activities, but they
grouped it very, very widely using both the Double Dragon barium-led monikers, which indicated
that they moved more towards this, let's say, single entity, single group scenario,
and it also resulted in a very wide description of techniques, tactics, and procedure,
apparently secure injection, also Cobalt strike, and again was used,
living off the land utilities, and so on, and so on.
And to kind of finish now, going through a timeline, is that in 2022 September,
the Department of Human Health Services, the United States, has published this briefing
about how the activity recently unfolded, how it affects the healthcare sector,
and as you can see here, similarly to the United States in the Department of Justice
Department of Justice position, they used the barium-winty naming convention, omitting
led one, and they very heavily underscored the links to the Five-Year Plan, so the
Chinese political documents that describes national goals in terms of economic
and strategic development, and how it links to the Chinese intelligence operators.
Okay, so that leaves us again with this question, who is this winty hacker and what can we do with
it? And if you were taking notes by the vendor and by which elements were used to link those
malware together, unfortunately, we can come to conclusion that by most of the time, it was
mainly tracked by the winty malware sample, and that there was involvement of stolen digital
certificates to sign the code, which is, of course, not much, either in the case of the
defense and in terms of adversary emulation. Because when we look at the kill chain
representation of the activity, we would be somewhere between weaponization, so understanding
how this tooling and code was developed, and maybe delivery as in trying to pass it with
the stolen certificates. But if it goes to get installed on the systems we protect,
it essentially goes through exploitation phase, it gets installed, and we are blind in those
spots if you want to also represent, defend and have the understanding of the whole kill chain.
I think we should rephrase the question into not who is winty or who is behind the keyboard,
but because of how your security organization works, how can you define this group on your own
and how can you make sure that it fits your needs of operation? So we might do it with the
analytical models. So instead of getting stuck on the APT41 or the double dragon barium lead
monikers, what I think that both internal intelligence teams or any intelligence team
that is tasked with tracking this kind of activity should do is essentially create an
analytical model that will act as a bucket to catch the operations, the intrusions that fit
your needs. So instead of having this one-to-one fit, I think the tracking should come from
understanding of what elements do you really need from winty. So what was the requirement?
Was it mentioned by the CSO that he wants to have this information by the group? Did it come up in
the Tiber exercise that you as a red team need to simulate these activities? What exactly are the
elements you need to focus on and either how it will impact your defense posture because you will
be doing some threat modeling or gap analysis or how else you can even use it for having
the defense efforts. And the solution, therefore, is to make your own winty model
and accounting for the three elements essentially of threat definitions, so intent,
opportunity, and capability. Think about what do you want to have achieved with this or how do you
want to see this group. So are you more interested in targeting of this industrial sector or gaming
and internet content companies? What capabilities do you need to track? Do you need to be so focused
on this winty model or do you want to include also supply chain attacks and so on? And to
think about why will you be following this reporting when you have this activity group.
So will you need to check if the next supply chain attack that gets detected
is also related to this and you might need to take a deeper look if you want to check in general
for the use of code signing certificates as a vector of making malware more evasive?
Do you see very heavily that your environment is infected with various iterations of winty
and you need to have robust defenses? This will all ultimately influence how you need to track
or how you might want to track the group by its manners.
So when we take into consideration all those examples and
presentation of activity like the techniques from the targeting used to the techniques through the
infrastructure, we can have this very wide list and very wide understanding
essentially something similar to what was done by ESET and Group IP of having this
let's say mosaic of different factors. And when we break it down into the diamond model
representation, so when we break it down into this adversary, victimology, infrastructure
and capabilities part on each vertex of the model, we can start thinking about
what is important to us and what is not so much. So when we looked at the top vertex,
so the adversary, we have from one side those operators that were very much concerned with the
financial gains, so they were stealing this in-game currency and so on. We had also this
apparent foreign intelligence apparatus that was tasked with the collection of industrial espionage.
And when we look at the capabilities, again we have quite a few features that when
grouped together will allow us to be able to pick and choose what matters to us.
So to give you a more specific example, if we look at the core intelligence block and what we did
is that we had this kind of specific representation in mind that took the victimology,
the use of malware, these specific tactics as stolen certificates.
And it created, let's say, its own activity cluster. So because we did not have visibility
like from signal or human intelligence into who is the adversary, this is not so important,
this is not by this point, like whether this was this financially motivated folks,
this were seasoned intelligence officers, we do not need to know that at this point.
But we can see the representation that they were doing this in DNS tunneling, they were using this
specific techniques of delivery, they had code similarities and so on, and because of tracking the
various malware representation, we can have this, we can have this, our own cluster that fits our
needs and allow us to make informed decisions about whether the next intrusion or the next
campaign or the next discovered piece of malware is in fact what fits into our understanding.
And I would very heavily recommend this approach because ultimately when you are using someone
else's naming, when you're using APT41, when you're using WinT, DoubleDragon and so on,
you do not have this control over what is going on. Because let's imagine you are a red team,
you are doing the threat intelligence-based ethical red teaming exercise, and you get from
the threat intelligence report that this APT41 is a group of interest, so we need to emulate that.
But essentially what happens there is you kind of give a space to Mandiant to have an input into
your exercise, because the next report might come up, like in the next month, in the next week and
so on, and it will turn into kind of feeding into your process. As opposed to that, when you have
your own cluster, either for defense or offensive research, you can have your own understanding and
even you can go further, like for the red team to develop further capabilities based on the
blueprint that will be prepared. And I believe that is more or less all from my side, I would
just like to, probably these references are barely visible, because as you might have noticed, there
were quite a few reports that I went through, and I would like to congratulate all of those
teams on the great work, threat intelligence, they work and they were doing. And with that,
thank you very much for your time.
